facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 29th August, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 568 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 29th August, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 568 of 1967. L. Sarin and R. L. Kohli, for the appellants.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court affirmed the conviction of the five appellants under section 302/149 I.P.C. with life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: This criminal appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the Allahabad High Court affirming the convinction of the five appellants, Bhajan Singh, Chain Singh, Baldeo Singh Jagat Singh and Gurbachan Singh under section 302/f49 I.P. C. and sentence of imprisonment for life on each of them.

facts.text: Bhajan Singh, Chain Singh and Jagat Singh convicted under section 147 I.P.C. and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year each.

anchor.surface_text: Bhajan Singh, Chain Singh and Jagat Singh have further been convinted under section 147 I. P. C. and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year each ,and the two other appellants have also been convinted under section 148 1. P. C. and sentenced to one and a half years rigorous, imprison- ment each.

facts.text: Baldev Singh and Gurbachan Singh convicted under section 148 I.P.C. and sentenced to one and a half years rigorous imprisonment each.

anchor.surface_text: Bhajan Singh, Chain Singh and Jagat Singh have further been convinted under section 147 I. P. C. and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year each ,and the two other appellants have also been convinted under section 148 1. P. C. and sentenced to one and a half years rigorous, imprison- ment each. Special leave was refused to Baldev Singh and Gurbachan Singh.

facts.text: Chain Singh and Baldeo Singh are sons of Bhajan Singh; Gurbachan Singh is the son of Jagat Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case may briefly be stated Chain Singh and Baldeo Singh are sons of Bhajan Singh, Gur- bachan Singh is the son of Jagat Singh. The deceased is Bakhsheesh Singh, who was the brother of Major Singh and a cousin of appellant, Bhajan Singh.

facts.text: Deceased Bakhsheesh Singh was brother of Major Singh and cousin of appellant Bhajan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case may briefly be stated Chain Singh and Baldeo Singh are sons of Bhajan Singh, Gur- bachan Singh is the son of Jagat Singh. The deceased is Bakhsheesh Singh, who was the brother of Major Singh and a cousin of appellant, Bhajan Singh.

facts.text: Major Singh purchased land in village Paivandkheri from Sohan Singh; Gurbachan Singh was in unlawful possession of 15-16 bighas of that land.

anchor.surface_text: Major Singh had purchased some land in their village Paivandkheri from one Sohan Singh and Gurbachan Singh was in unlawful possession of over 15 to 16 bighas of the said land. There was litigation between Gurbachan Singh and Major Singh in respect of this land.

facts.text: Gurbachan Singh sold his entire land including disputed area to Bhajan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Gurbachan Singh subsequently sold his entire land including the disputed area to Bhajan Singh. Thereafter Major Singh and his father Ujagar Singh asked Bhajan Singh to give up possession over the land purchased by Major Singh

facts.text: Day before occurrence, Major Singh and Ujagar Singh asked Bhajan Singh to give up possession and suggested going to Patwari; Bhajan agreed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Major Singh and his father Ujagar Singh asked Bhajan Singh to give up possession over the land purchased by Major Singh and, on the day before the occurrence, su.- gested to him that, they should go to the Patwari and settle the matter to which Bhajan Singh agreed.

facts.text: On September 17, 1964, at about 11.30 A.M., Bakhsheesh Singh started on cycle to Patwari's house with papers regarding disputed land, followed by Ujagar Singh and Major Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17, 1964, at about 11.30 A.M. Bakhsheesh started on a cycle for the house of the Patwari with papers in connection with the disputed land. He was followed on foot, by his father, Ujagar Singh and brother Major Singh.

facts.text: When Bakhsheesh had gone 20-25 paces from house, five appellants accosted him: Baldeo Singh with spear, Gurbachan with gandasa, others with lathis.

anchor.surface_text: When Bakhsheesh Singh had hardly gone a distance of about 20 or 25 paces from his house, the five appellants accosted him, Baldeo Singh was armed with a spear and Gurbachan Singh with a gandasa and the three other appellants were armed with lathis.

facts.text: Bhajan Singh caught hold of Bakhsheesh Singh and incited others to beat him.

anchor.surface_text: Bakhsheesh Singh got down from the cycle and Bhaian Singh caught hold of him and incited the other appellants to beat him. Baksheesh Singh requested the appellants to accompany him to the Patwari to settle the dispute

facts.text: Jagat Singh said they would settle on the spot.

anchor.surface_text: Bakhsheesh Singh requested the appellants to accompany him to the Patwari to settle the dispute, but Jagat Singh said that they would settle it on the spot.

facts.text: Baldev Singh gave spear blow to Bakhsheesh Singh's abdomen; Gurbachan gave gandasa blow to head; Chain Singh beat with lathi.

anchor.surface_text: Baldev Singh then give a ,spear blow to Bakhsheesh Singh, Gurbachan Singh gave him a gandasa blow on the head and Chain Singh beat him with his lathi. Thereafter the appellants ran away.

facts.text: Occurrence witnessed by Ujagar Singh (PW3), Major Singh (PW2), Jogendar Kaur (widow PW4), Sadhu Singh, Sardari Singh, Prakash Singh (servants).

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence was witnessed by Ujagar Singh  P.W. 3 , Major Singh  P.W. 2  and Jogendar Kaur, widow of the deceased W. 4  and Sadhu Singh, Sardari Singh and Prakash Singh, who were servants of Ujagar Singh.

facts.text: Bakhsheesh Singh injured in abdomen, intestines came out; bandaged with turbans; taken to PS Afzalgarh; FIR lodged by Major Singh at 12.45 P.M.

anchor.surface_text: Bakhsheesh Singh was injured in the abdomen and his intestines came out. The injury was bandaged with the turbans of the deceased and Ujagar Singh and he was taken to the police Station, Afzalgarh, where a first information report was lodged by Major Singh at 12.45 P.M.

facts.text: Bakhsheesh taken to hospital at Sherkot, examined by Dr. Yogendra Pal (PW4 in Committing Court); then to District Hospital Bijnor.

anchor.surface_text: The police sent him to the hospital at Sherkot where Dr. Yogendra Pal  PW 4 in the Committing Court  examined him. From there he was taken to the District Hospital, Bijnor.

facts.text: Dying declaration Ex. Ke-8 recorded at 9.30 P.M. by Tahsildar Magistrate Shri Balbir Singh (W1).

anchor.surface_text: As his condition was serious, a dying declaration  Ex. Ke-8  was recorded at 9.30 P.M. by the Tahsildar Magistrate, Shri Balbir Singh W. 1 . Bakhsheesh Singh died next day, September 18, 1964, in the afternoon.

facts.text: Bakhsheesh Singh died on September 18, 1964, in the afternoon.

anchor.surface_text: As his condition was serious, a dying declaration  Ex. Ke-8  was recorded at 9.30 P.M. by the Tahsildar Magistrate, Shri Balbir Singh W. 1 . Bakhsheesh Singh died next day, September 18, 1964, in the afternoon.

facts.text: Postmortem by Dr. P.P. Agarwal on 19th September, 1964; death due to shock and haemorrhage from injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Postmortem examination was performed by Dr. P. P. Agarwal on 19th September, 1964. According to the Doctor death was due to shock and haemorrhage from the injuries.

facts.text: Gurbachan Singh and Chain Singh had simple injuries, not reported to police, examined by Dr. K.C. Gupta (DW4) on September 20, 1964 at 4.00 P.M.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Gurbachan Singh and Chain Singh had some Simple injuries on their person but they did number report to the police number were they examined by Dr. K. C. Gupta  D. W. 4  earlier than September 20, 1964, at 4.00 P. M.

facts.text: Defence plea: absolute denial by Bhajan Singh, Baldeo Singh, Jagat Singh; different version by Chain Singh and Gurbachan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The defence plea is an absolute denial by Bhajan Singh, Baldeo Singh and Jagat Singh while Chain Singh and Gurbachan Singh gave a different version of the occurrence.

facts.text: According to Chain Singh and Gurbachan Singh: they were grazing cattle by canal; Sardar Singh and Bakhsheesh came, abused, grappling; Major gave karauli blow.

anchor.surface_text: According to Chain Singh he and Gurbachan Singh were grazing their cattle by the side of the canal when one Sardar Singh and Bakhsheesh Singh came there. Bakhsheesh Singh abused them and there was grappling with him. Major Singh came from behind with a karauli and gave him a blow with it.

facts.text: Supreme Court relied on evidence of eye witnesses PW2, PW3, PW4, corroborated by dying declaration and medical evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has relied, as the Sessions Judge earlier did, upon the evidence of the three eye witnesses and has found that their evidence was corroborated by the dying declaration as well as by the medical evidence, as properly scanned by the courts.

facts.text: Supreme Court found no reason to disbelieve testimony of eye witnesses despite them being related to deceased.

anchor.surface_text: We have perused the evidence of the three eye witnesses and could number find any ground to disbelieve their testimony. The learned counsel also could number draw our attention to any serious infirmity in the evidence except characterising their testimony as interested.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld that five accused were members of unlawful assembly with common object to kill Bakhsheesh Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that all the five accused came armed with deadly weapons and one of them, namely, Bhajan Singh was the first to catch bold of the deceased and shouted beat the sala, while accused Jagat Singh said that they would number go to the Patwari and decide the matter on the spot.

facts.text: Convictions under section 147 and 148 set aside as subsumed in 302/149.

anchor.surface_text: Since all the accused are convinted under section 302/149 P.C. there is numberfurther necessity, in the circumstances of this case, for their separate convition under section 147 and 148 of the Indian Penal Code. Conviction and sentence of Bhajan Singh, Chain Singh and Jagat Singh under section 147 I.P.C. set aside.

issues.text: Whether in an appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution this Court should interfere with the concurrent conclusions of the two courts below with regard to the appreciation of evidence of the witnesses

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution this Court is very slow to interfere with the concurrent conclusions of the two courts below with regard to the appreciation of evidence of the witnesses. The accused must be able to make out an extraordinary case of gross and palpable injustice

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in relying upon the testimony of partisan witnesses related to the deceased

anchor.surface_text: Even so, the learned counsel for the appellants submits that the High Court has erred in relying upon the testimony of these partisan witnesses since they are all related to the deceased. But even the deceased is the cousin of the appellant, Bhajan Singh.

issues.text: Whether the eye witnesses' statements are falsified by the medical evidence

anchor.surface_text: Counsel further submits that their statements are falsified by the medical evidence. He also submits that the eye witnesses have not given any explanation for the injuries received by the accused

issues.text: Whether failure of eye witnesses to explain injuries on accused requires rejection of their evidence

anchor.surface_text: and, therefore, their evidence should be rejected. The-same grounds were also pressed into service before the trial court and in the High Court and both the courts repelled the same with good reasons

issues.text: Whether the common object of the unlawful assembly was only to beat Bakhsheesh Singh and not to kill him such that charge under section 302/149 IPC has not been established

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel contends that the common object of the unlawful assembly is only to beat Bakhsheesh Singh and not to kill him. He submits that even on the evidence accepted by the High Court charge under section 302/149 I.P.C. has not been established against the accused.

issues.text: Whether section 149 IPC applies under its second limb even if original common object was only beating given the use of deadly weapons and knowledge of likely death

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel, however., fails to take notice of the fact that section 149 has got two limbs If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, or such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed

issues.text: Whether there is any circumstance to bring the case under section 304 IPC instead of 302 IPC

anchor.surface_text: There is no circumstance in the case which can bring down this case to one under section 304 I.P.C. The intention was clear to kill Bakhsheesh Singh and all the accused are guilty of the offence charged namely, section 302/149 I.P.C.

issues.text: Whether separate convictions under sections 147 and 148 IPC are necessary or sustainable when there is conviction under section 302/149 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Since all the accused are convicted under section 302/149 P.C. there is nofurther necessity, in the circumstances of this case, for their separate conviction under section 147 and 148 of the Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: This Court should not interfere under Article 136 with concurrent findings on evidence unless extraordinary case of gross injustice

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution this Court is very slow to interfere with the concurrent conclusions of the two courts below with regard to the appreciation of evidence of the witnesses. The accused must be able to make out an extraordinary case of gross and palpable injustice

arguments.claim: Section 149 IPC applies via second limb: members knew offence likely even if common object was beating given deadly weapons

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel, however., fails to take notice of the fact that section 149 has got two limbs If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, or such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed

arguments.claim: No circumstance to reduce to 304 IPC; intention to kill clear

anchor.surface_text: There is no circumstance in the case which can bring down this case to one under section 304 I.P.C. The intention was clear to kill Bakhsheesh Singh and all the accused are guilty of the offence charged namely, section 302/149 I.P.C.

arguments.claim: No separate conviction under 147/148 necessary when convicted under 302/149

anchor.surface_text: Since all the accused are convicted under section 302/149 P.C. there is nofurther necessity, in the circumstances of this case, for their separate conviction under section 147 and 148 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.text: This Court is very slow to interfere with concurrent conclusions of lower courts on evidence appreciation under Article 136 unless extraordinary case of gross injustice made out, and no such case exists here.

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal under Article 136 of the Constitution this Court is very slow to interfere with the concurrent conclusions of the two courts below with regard to the appreciation of evidence of the witnesses. The accused must be able to make out an extraordinary case of gross and palpable injustice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reviewed evidence; concur with lower courts' repulsion of arguments on partisan nature, medical inconsistency, and unexplained injuries on accused.

holdings.text: Testimony of eye-witnesses PW2, PW3, PW4 reliable despite being related to deceased and interested.

anchor.surface_text: We have perused the evidence of the three eye witnesses and could not find any ground to disbelieve their testimony. The learned counsel also could not draw our attention to any serious infirmity in the evidence except characterising their testimony as interested.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Perused evidence; no serious infirmity beyond mere interest; corroborated by dying declaration and medical evidence.

holdings.text: Eye-witness statements not falsified by medical evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel further submits that their statements are falsified by the medical evidence. He also submits that the eye witnesses have not given any explanation for the injuries received by the accused

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts scanned medical evidence properly and found corroboration; Supreme Court concurs.

holdings.text: Failure to explain injuries on accused does not require rejection of eye-witness evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The-same grounds were also pressed into service before the trial court and in the High Court and both the courts repelled the same with good reasons

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arguments already repelled by trial and High Court with good reasons; Supreme Court concurs.

holdings.text: All five accused were members of unlawful assembly with common object to kill Bakhsheesh Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that all the five accused came armed with deadly weapons and one of them, namely, Bhajan Singh was the first to catch hold of the deceased and shouted beat the sala, while accused Jagat Singh said that they would not go to the Patwari and decide the matter on the spot.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Armed with deadly weapons, intercepted deceased, Bhajan caught and incited, Jagat refused Patwari and said settle on spot; version accepted by lower courts.

holdings.text: Even assuming original common object was only beating, accused liable under second limb of section 149 IPC as armed with deadly weapons and knew murder likely.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel, however., fails to take notice of the fact that section 149 has got two limbs If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, or such as the members of that assembly knew to be likely to be committed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s149 has two limbs; deadly weapons (spear, gandasa, lathis) used desperately imply knowledge of lethal consequence.

holdings.text: No circumstances to reduce offence to section 304 IPC; intention to kill clear; all accused guilty under 302/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: There is no circumstance in the case which can bring down this case to one under section 304 I.P.C. The intention was clear to kill Bakhsheesh Singh and all the accused are guilty of the offence charged namely, section 302/149 I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fatal injuries to abdomen and head with deadly weapons show clear intention to kill.

holdings.text: No necessity for separate convictions under sections 147 and 148 IPC when convicted under 302/149 IPC; convictions under 147 set aside for Bhajan, Chain, Jagat; 148 subsumed.

anchor.surface_text: Since all the accused are convicted under section 302/149 P.C. there is nofurther necessity, in the circumstances of this case, for their separate conviction under section 147 and 148 of the Indian Penal Code. Conviction and sentence of Bhajan Singh, Chain Singh and Jagat Singh under section 147 I.P.C. set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 302/149 conviction subsumes rioting offences in circumstances.
